subject: Re: [junit] Digest Number 322
msgSnippet: Excuse me. I did not claim that there was *no* useful discussion here. I did claim that there is a lot of noise. There is. You can try to argue against that
messageBody:
Excuse me.

I did not claim that there was *no* useful discussion here. I did claim that
there is a lot of noise. There is. You can try to argue against that all you
want, and you'd be wrong. Even today I saw a message saying, "I think that's
a good question. I think an answer would be useful."

DO WE REALLY NEED TO SAY THAT?! Do you really need to write to a mailing
list, "Yeah. I wanna know too!" OF COURSE YOU WANT TO KNOW! That's why you
read the list. That's enough, thanks.

Come on, folks. I was new at this once, too. Someone told me, "Stop doing
that." I learned. Don't feel like you should be treated any differently. The
bottom line is that there are far too many "Would you tell me exactly what
to do in order to test my application?" questions. That is NOT what this
list is for!

>>>JUnit is a new thing for many people and this list must also be
available to new users and not only to those who have already
got an answer to all questions.<<<

I never said that it should not be accessible to new users. It should not,
however, be used as a SUBSTITUTE for learning; it is supposed to help us
learn about JUnit. Those who treat it like a magic answer box are the ones
that bother me.

Incidentally, I learned about JUnit long before this list appeared. Do you
think I'm some supergenius? No. I read, I tried and then I read some more.
When I couldn't figure it out, I searched for answers. Why can't other
people do that?

JBR.

---- Begin original message ----

--- In junit@y..., Eric Vought <evought@q...> wrote:
and
--- In junit@y..., "J. B. Rainsberger" <jbrains762@h...> wrote:
.....
>Ladies and Gentlemen:
>
>I am frankly quite concerned with the quality of the exchanges
>going on here in the last several weeks. It appears that many
>people think there are "magic formulas" for working with JUnit.
>As a result, they ask silly questions like, "How do I test an
>EJB with JUnit????" The people who know the answer get so
>tired of writing, "Search this list. Try it. What are you
>having trouble testing?" that they simply stop responding.
>As a result, questions are not being answered.
................

I don't agree with these opinions. I think there has been
very good questions and answers (discussions) here. Of course
it is good if the answers can already be found in a FAQ
but remember that the FAQ is something that is maintained
usually by one person as on a list like this you can have several
views. Take as an example the answers yesterday of why you should use
JUnit. I am sure you can find data on this already somewhere else.

JUnit is a new thing for many people and this list must also be
available to new users and not only to those who have already
got an answer to all questions.

Kaarle Kaila
